awd_titl_txt: Brown Adipose Tissue, Biological Variation and Senescence in Humans
awd_abstract_narration:
Fundamental research in human biology includes efforts to understand the nature and tempo of human life history, including the timing and characteristics of aging in various physiological systems. This project focuses on hot flashes as an aspect of human variation during reproductive aging, and tests the hypothesis that brown adipose tissue - a type of fat that generates heat - may be a factor associated with hot flash experience. The study will extend our knowledge about human variation in both brown adipose tissue and hot flash experience, with particular attention to the relation between hot flashes (subjectively reported and biometrically measured), brown adipose tissue, body composition, and climate.  The study will address human variation in the ability to generate and dissipate heat, and findings will contribute to knowledge about modern human biological adaptations. The outcomes of this research may also inform clinical understanding and treatments of conditions that affect many women in the U.S., including hot flashes and obesity. Results from this study will be shared with participants and communities through public talks, brochures and a project website.  Undergraduate women will assist with the research, thereby gaining valuable experience in STEM fields. 

When brown adipose tissue is activated by cool or cold conditions, it creates heat in an effort to keep the body warm.  The central hypothesis of this study is that brown adipose tissue activation may produce enough heat to cause hot flashes.  The  aim is to explore the role of brown adipose tissue activation in the experience of hot flashes among peri-menopausal and early postmenopausal women, aged 45-55, during the cold months -- from late October to early April -- in western Massachusetts.  The investigators hypothesize that (1) women with more brown adipose tissue activity will be more likely to objectively demonstrate and subjectively report hot flashes, (2) brown adipose tissue activity is more likely to be associated with hot flashes in heavier women, and (3) acclimatization to heat and (4) exposure to lower ambient temperatures amplify the association between brown adipose tissue activity and hot flashes.  The study involves face-to-face interviews about hot flashes and factors associated with hot flashes, physical activity, and stress; body measurements (height, weight, skinfolds, waist and hip circumferences); body composition by bioelectrical impedance; an estimation of brown adipose tissue activity with an infrared camera before and after dipping a hand into cool (64oF) water for five minutes; an ambulatory hot flash monitor worn for 24 hours to record both objective and subjective hot flashes; and an Actigraph GT9X watch to measure activity and sleep patterns for the same 24 hours.  On the hot flash monitor pouch, there will also be a small ambulatory gauge to measure air temperature and humidity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this research on Brown Adipose Tissue, Biological Variation and Senescence in Humans was to explore the association between brown adipose tissue (BAT) activity and hot flashes (HFs) among women at midlife.  We explored this association because women were asking, “How can I be hot and cold at the same time?” for example when watching their children play ice hockey (a common example).  We thought that cooling down beside an ice rink might provoke the BAT to generate enough heat to increase the core body temperature and trigger a HF.  The study took place during the cold months in western Massachusetts, from October through April 2019-2023.  Our hypothesis was that women with more BAT activity would be more likely to demonstrate HFs via an ambulatory monitor and/or report HFs on a questionnaire or via button pushes on the ambulatory monitor.  We also collaborated with exercise physiologist Sarah Witkowski (Smith College) to understand the relationship between HFs, physical activity, and sedentary behavior.  Opportunistically, we had the chance to compare stress, depression, general symptoms, and physical activity across the time periods of pre-/early Covid, mid-pandemic, and later-pandemic (after the vaccines became widely available). 

We collected data from 270 women aged 45-55.  Participants were interviewed for demographic, health, and menopause-related information; they were measured for height, weight, skinfolds, and circumferences; and they participated in thermal imaging to estimate BAT activity.  For example, we thought that current BAT activity (thermal imaging) might be associated with childhood or current cold exposure (questionnaire data), but we did not find any association.  Study participants also wore ambulatory HF, temperature, humidity, and physical activity monitors for about 24 hours after the lab visit.  We thought that higher temperatures might trigger more HFs, but we have not found evidence to support that idea except, perhaps, at night.  Those analyses are ongoing.  

With regard to the central question of the study, we divided self-reported HFs into "not bothersome" (54.8%) and "bothersome" (45.2%) categories.  Estimated BAT activity was significantly positively associated with an increase in the likelihood of self-reported (from the questionnaire) bothersome HFs.  In a statistical model adjusting for menopausal status, body mass index, and financial comfort, an increase in one unit of BAT activity more than doubled the likelihood of a bothersome HF.  Thus, the central hypothesis of our grant proposal was supported.

We also found that postmenopausal women had significantly less estimated BAT activity compared to pre- or perimenopausal women, and BAT activity was not related to measures of general fatness.  However, women with lower BAT activity averaged larger waist-to-hip circumference ratios compared to other women in the sample.  It may be that the increased risk for cardiometabolic diseases after menopause is, in part, associated with a decline in BAT activity.  This should be further examined in future studies. 

With regard to COVID, we found no significant differences in health-related measures or physical activity across the pre-/early, mid-, or later stages of the pandemic.  However, our analysis of open-ended responses revealed that while some women suffered negative health-related effects during the pandemic, others experienced conditions that improved their health and well-being. That may be why the initial comparisons did not show any change.  Individual negative and positive changes across the study sample resulted in no differences when results were averaged.

Finally, using questionnaire physical activity data and 24-hour ambulatory HF monitoring, we evaluated the effect of physical activity and sedentary time on HF outcomes.  Increasing sitting time by one hour was associated with a 7% increase in the rate of objectively measured but not subjectively reported HFs during sleep. 

Graduate student Sofiya Shreyer was the project manager for the entire four-year study.  She will use this data to investigate night sweats for her dissertation.  This four-year study also provided hands-on research experience for nine undergraduate research assistants.  Three undergraduate honors theses have been based on this project: Cycling Back: How Reproductive History Affects the Timing of Natural Menopause by Alessandra Loffredo, who found that age at natural menopause was significantly positively associated with age at last birth.  Menopause and Body Composition by Kripa Anand, who found no relationship between menopausal status and any measure of adiposity or fat distribution. And The Mirena IUD in Relation to Symptoms at Midlife by Ava Warner (ongoing).

What we learn about BAT and HFs has relevance for our understanding of symptoms at midlife as well as human adaptation to the cold.  To our knowledge, this was the first study of HFs in relation to BAT, and also the first study that collected continuous temperature and humidity measures concurrent with the use of the ambulatory HF monitor.  HFs are a common and uncomfortable symptom associated with the menopausal transition.  Our work is showing that BAT activity during the winter may help explain some of the variation in symptom experience.
